Are there infinitely many primes $p$ such that $p=2^kq+1$ for some prime $q$ and $k\geq 0$? Or $p=2^k3^lq+1$?



This is mentioned in problem B46 of Guy's collection \cite{Gu04}.




References


[Gu04] Guy, Richard K., Unsolved problems in number theory. (2004), xviii+437.

knowledge.progressSummary: SURVEYED: Formalized both forms (2^k·q+1 and 2^k·3^l·q+1). Proved examples and non-examples with interval_cases.
builtItems: form1_3, form1_5, form1_7, form1_11, form1_13 theorems
insights: Form 1: p-1 = 2^k·q where q is odd prime (single odd prime factor)
Form 2: p-1 = 2^k·3^l·q (allows power of 3 as well)
Form 2 is strictly more general (includes form 1 with l=0)
